properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dense fog patches with tricky driving conditions this afternoon. Areas of dense fog with near zero visibility will continue to affect areas near Lake Ontario and Lake Erie this afternoon. Motorists should drive according to the weather and road conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. Fog is expected to lift later this afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T23:49:00-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dense fog patches with tricky driving conditions this afternoon. Areas of dense fog with near zero visibility will continue to affect the region this afternoon. In addition, with temperatures near or a little below the zero degree mark in some areas, untreated roads may suddenly become icy and slippery. Motorists should drive according to the weather and road conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. Fog is expected to lift later this afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibilities due to snow and blowing snow are expected Wednesday afternoon and evening. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 2, 2020 16:00 local Mountain time - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Golden due to high concentrations of dust that are expected to persist today. This advisory will be updated today. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have underlying medical conditions such as breathing or lung conditions, hay fever, asthma or persons who react strongly to dust. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheeze, follow the advice of your health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-landwater/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-04T04:50:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-03T12:51:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1640999212.2020
Area: East Columbia
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected later this week. Time span: Wednesday evening into Friday morning. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, Labrador Straits to Makkovik. Snowfall amounts: 10 to 20 cm with possibly higher amounts (by Thursday night). Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Wednesday evening along the strait and spread northward overnight. Strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow Wednesday night in the southeast and Thursday along the mid Labrador coast. Snow will taper to flurries early Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T06:49:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, mild temperatures and gusty winds are expected mid-week. Time span: Wednesday and Wednesday night. Locations: central and eastern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm (higher amounts possible over southern areas). Rainfall warnings have been issued for Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre. Maximum wind gusts: southerly 70 to 100 km/h (strongest near the coast). Remarks: Rain will begin along the south coast of Newfoundland on Wednesday morning and will spread over central and eastern parts of the island by early Wednesday afternoon. The rain may be preceded by a short period of freezing rain over some areas, but temperatures are anticipated to rise quickly over most locations. The mild air combined with the rain could cause significant snowmelt and runoff. The rain is forecast to taper off Wednesday night. In addition, a period of strong southerly winds is expected over most areas on Wednesday night. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T06:04:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T14:05:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3541408062.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather expected over Eastern Quebec. A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It will bring snow accompanied by strong winds causing blowing snow locally. Snowfall amounts could exceed 15 centimetres through Thursday. The eastern Lower North Shore could also see a period of freezing rain. Conditions should improve gradually Thursday over the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula. For the Lower North Shore, the strong winds will persist overnight Thursday. These poor weather conditions could delay travel. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-04T08:39:31-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, snow and strong winds expected later this week. Time span: Wednesday through Thursday. Locations: western and southwestern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm, with higher amounts along the south coast (Wednesday). Rainfall warnings have been issued from Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm or more (Thursday). Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 80 to 100 km/h (Wednesday). Wind warnings have been issued for Bay St. George to Corner Brook and may be extended further north along the west coast. Remarks: Rain will begin over southwestern Newfoundland on Wednesday morning and will spread up the west coast on Wednesday afternoon. The rain may be preceded by a short period of freezing rain over some areas, but temperatures are anticipated to rise quickly over most locations. Colder air will return Wednesday night, causing the rain to change to snow. Snow will then likely continue through Thursday and may be heavy over some areas, especially along the Long Range Mountains. In addition, a period of strong southeasterly winds is expected over most areas on Wednesday afternoon or evening. Gusty west to southwesterlies will then follow for Thursday. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T06:13:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T14:14:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2135646056.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h. Locations: Happy Valley-Goose Bay to Cartwright and Black Tickle. Time span: Wednesday night through Thursday. Remarks: Snow will develop Wednesday night with strengthening northeasterly winds resulting in reduced visibilities in blowing snow. The snow and wind will gradually ease during the day on Thursday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T11:52:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T19:53:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0955236210.2020
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It will bring hazardous winter conditions. Precipitation will begin midday Wednesday as freezing rain before changing to snow during the afternoon. Total snowfall accumulations could reach 25 centimetres until Thursday. In addition, the strong northeast winds will cause local blowing snow Wednesday afternoon and in the evening. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

Area: Chevery
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Significant snowfall, ice pellets, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. Total snow and ice pellet amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Time span: early Wednesday evening until near midnight Wednesday night. Remarks: Snow mixed at times with ice pellets will develop Wednesday evening, with a risk of freezing rain over some areas. The snow is expected to be heavy, at times, and will be accompanied by strong winds resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow is forecast to change to a mixture of rain and snow near midnight, and to taper to flurries before morning on Thursday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T11:52:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T19:53:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3413877055.2020

properties.Summary:

Temperatures should moderate Wednesday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected. Time span: Wednesday afternoon until late Wednesday evening. Locations: Great Northern Peninsula. Snowfall and Ice pellet amounts: 2 to 4 cm. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets are expected to develop Wednesday afternoon with possibly a significant period of freezing rain. The precipitation is expected to taper off to drizzle as temperatures rise above zero later in the evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T11:43:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T19:44:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1595449440.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 25 mm Locations: Southern Newfoundland, from Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre Time span: Wednesday morning to evening Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, will begin late in the morning Wednesday and continue through the day before changing to snow Wednesday night. Snow will be at time heavy from Channel-Port aux Basques to Burgeo where winter storm warnings have been issued. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of the rainfall. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T11:35:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T19:36:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3795245525.2020
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: easterly 70 km/h, except locally 100 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: Bay St. George, Corner Brook and vicinity. Time span: near noon Wednesday to early Wednesday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-04T06:15:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T14:16:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2493387285.2020
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -55 will continue this morning. Slight moderation is expected midday with extreme cold wind chills returning tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-04T07:14:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T15:15:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3902665909.2020
Area: Cambridge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A major winter storm is expected. A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It will give total snowfall amounts of 30 to 40 centimetres through Thursday. Strong winds will locally cause blowing snow. These poor weather conditions could delay travel. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-04T08:30:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T16:31:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2520598828.2020
Area: Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A strong Pacific cold front will bring heavy snow to the route tonight. The snow will develop near the summit late this afternoon and then the snow level lowers to near 400 metres tonight as the front crosses the region. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 20 cm are expected by Wednesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-04T05:04:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-03T13:05:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1139352924.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada
